name: GJ 143
scenarioDescription:
The GJ 143 Exoplanetary System


Overview

GJ 143 is a star with 0.73 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.69 times its radius. It is located 53.26127479999999 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 3.8 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

GJ 143 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the GJ 143 system

GJ 143 b

GJ 143 b was discovered by the Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS) observatory using the Transit method. The mass of GJ 143 b is 22.7 times the mass of Earth. The radius of GJ 143 b is 2.61 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, GJ 143 b is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.


GJ 143 c

GJ 143 c was discovered by the Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS) observatory using the Transit method. The mass of GJ 143 c is 3.7 times the mass of Earth. The radius of GJ 143 c is 0.892 that of Earth. At 3.7 Earth masses, GJ 143 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system GJ 143, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS).
